title: How To Read Code Like A Pro
summary: The first thing you want to do when reading code is open up the declaration and read the code like you’re reading a book. The declaration section contains all the information you need to know about how the code is written and what it actually does. If you see a line of code that has a lot of abbreviations, acronyms, or words you aren’t familiar with, try to read it as though you were reading a sentence in English. Keep track of the terms that you see most often while reading code by keeping a dictionary beside you.

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...n}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...n,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`The way you understand code today will determine the speed with which you can read and comprehend code tomorrow. After all, no one is born a coding expert; that designation is something you must earn by constantly challenging yourself to improve your skills. However, reading and understanding code isn\u2019t always easy, especially when it\u2019s written in a foreign language or has certain nuances that are beyond your current understanding.
Reading code like an expert means more than just knowing what words mean and their general significance. It also means being able to dive deeper into the syntax of how those words are put together so that you can understand what they mean in context and intention. Read on to discover some tips for reading code like a pro!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

content.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"Don\u2019t Be Disappointed By What You See"),mdx("p",null,"When you open up a file and find a bunch of lines of code that seem to make no sense whatsoever, remember that you\u2019re reading the code from the inside out. When a programmer writes a piece of code, they\u2019re writing it for themselves first and foremost. They\u2019re using their own shorthand and abbreviations to keep things tidy and easy to understand for themselves. This is especially true in languages like JavaScript that are more forgiving than other programming languages. Code that looks like absolute gibberish up front is often a sign that the programmer has been keeping things tidy for themselves. It\u2019s also a sign that you need to keep reading to understand what\u2019s happening."),mdx("h2",null,"Read the Declaration (The Header)"),mdx("p",null,"The first thing you want to do when reading code is open up the declaration and read the code like you\u2019re reading a book. The declaration section will typically contain all the information you need to know about how the code is written and what it actually does. It\u2019s the equivalent of reading the \u201Cabout\u201D or \u201Csummary\u201D section of a book. If there\u2019s something you don\u2019t understand, you can be sure it will be explained in this first section. It\u2019s often where you\u2019ll be able to find the name of the programmer who wrote the code, what language it was written in, and a general overview of what the code is intended to do. While you\u2019re reading the declaration, be sure to keep an eye out for words that you don\u2019t understand. If there\u2019s a word you don\u2019t know, be sure to look it up and write it down. This will help you remember what each word means and how it\u2019s being used in the code."),mdx("h2",null,"Don\u2019t Be Scared of Vocab"),mdx("p",null,"One of the biggest things that can trip up a beginner coder trying to read code is getting scared of certain words or terms. If you see a line of code that has a lot of abbreviations, acronyms, or words you aren\u2019t familiar with, don\u2019t shy away from it. Instead, try to read that line of code as though you were reading a sentence in English. Break it down into its components and try to understand what each part means. You\u2019ll often find that the scary, mysterious lines of code are actually tame when you break them down. They\u2019re just words that convey a slightly different meaning than the words you\u2019re used to."),mdx("h2",null,"Don\u2019t Be Shy About Skimming"),mdx("p",null,"We\u2019re all busy, and sometimes you just can\u2019t sit down and read a file from start to finish. If that\u2019s the case, don\u2019t feel bad about skimming the file for the information you need. If you know you\u2019ll need to understand a function or module, don\u2019t feel bad about just reading the parts of the code that pertain to that function. Especially when you\u2019re first starting out, it\u2019s normal to just want to know the things that directly relate to your work. Reading the entire file isn\u2019t always necessary, and you shouldn\u2019t feel bad about skimming if you don\u2019t have the time to read it in its entirety."),mdx("h2",null,"Keep Track of Key Words"),mdx("p",null,"Coding languages are often full of abbreviations and acronyms, so you\u2019ll definitely want to keep track of the terms that you see most often while reading code. You can do this by keeping a dictionary of code terms or abbreviations beside you while you\u2019re reading. This will help you remember what each word means so that you don\u2019t have to keep flipping back to the dictionary every few seconds. It will also make it much easier for you to understand what each line of code is doing."),mdx("p",null,"Keeping track of the most common words in your language of choice will make it much easier for you to understand what\u2019s happening in other people\u2019s code. It\u2019s never fun to be reading someone else\u2019s code and not understand what it\u2019s doing. This is particularly true if you\u2019re a beginner coder and you\u2019re trying to understand code written by an expert. Keeping a dictionary by your side will help you avoid that issue and will allow you to read the code as easily as if it was written for you."),mdx("h2",null,"Read the Code"),mdx("p",null,"Once you\u2019ve gotten through the declaration and you\u2019ve understood the abbreviations and terms being used, you can actually read the code. However, this doesn\u2019t mean reading the code from top to bottom. Instead, you should be reading the code from the inside out."),mdx("p",null,"When you read from the inside out, you\u2019re reading the code as a whole instead of reading each line in sequence. This will help you understand the entire flow and purpose of the code so that you can better understand how it works. This is particularly important when reading code written by an expert. When you read the code from the inside out, you can see everything that\u2019s happening in one fell swoop. This will help you understand what the code is doing as a whole, as well as where each line of code fits into the overall picture."),mdx("h2",null,"Take Breaks and Help Your Brain"),mdx("p",null,"While reading code can be overwhelming and difficult at times, it\u2019s important not to give up. If you\u2019re feeling like you\u2019re just not getting it, take a break and come back to the code later when you\u2019re feeling fresh. It\u2019s also important to remember that you\u2019re not expected to read and understand code perfectly on the first try. Even if you\u2019re reading code that was written by an expert, don\u2019t expect to understand it perfectly the first time you read it. Instead, approach reading code with a patient and humble attitude. You\u2019re not expected to understand everything immediately, but you are expected to try your best and keep trying until you understand."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"The road to becoming an expert coder is long and challenging. In fact, it\u2019s one of the most difficult tech fields to get started in as a beginner. But it\u2019s also one of the most lucrative careers you can choose to pursue. The average software engineer salary is around $100K per year, which is even more impressive when you consider that the average age of software engineers is only 29! If you want to start a new career in coding but feel like you\u2019re starting at square one, we have some advice for you. As someone who has been coding for over 10 years now, I can tell you with complete certainty that great coders are made and not born. Anyone can learn how to code if they are willing to work hard at it and adopt some good habits along the way. Here are some tips on how you can get started today:"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: The Best Coding Languages to Learn

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Having the skills to code can be an extremely useful asset in your professional and personal life. There is a huge demand for coders right now, and it is only going to continue growing in the future. Some of the most successful people today got there because they mastered a coding language and used it to their advantage. Whether you are looking for a new career opportunity or something you can use on a personal level, learning to code is something that will not only expand your mind but also open up so many doors for you.
Coding languages might seem intimidating at first glance, but once you get past the initial weirdness of reading something that seems like a foreign language, they are actually fairly straightforward. Even if you have no programming experience whatsoever, this article will give you all the information you need to begin your coder journey and find the perfect coding language for your needs.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: The Best Coding Resources for Beginners

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...n}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...n,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`New to coding? There are a lot of resources out there, but they can be overwhelming. Which ones are worth your time? How do you find the best ones? The coding space is constantly growing and changing. There are new tools, sites, and concepts popping up every day. Navigating this landscape as a beginner can be difficult.
Coding is an in-demand skill that has been growing rapidly in demand over the last few years. More and more people want to learn how to code, but there isn\u2019t always an easy resource for beginners looking to get started. With so many options out there, it can be difficult to know where to start learning the basics of coding. Even if you\u2019re not a complete beginner, these are great places to continue learning about coding and even advance your knowledge on specific topics that interest you most.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: The Benefits of Learning to Code

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Learning to code is challenging, but it can also be incredibly rewarding. It has become a highly sought after skill in recent years, with the demand for coders rising year on year. There are many reasons why learning to code could be beneficial for you as a career. The opportunities available to those who know how to code are considerably expanded.
Coding has become an essential skill in almost every industry, including marketing and sales, business analysis, data science, cyber security, artificial intelligence and robotics. Learning how to code opens up opportunities in almost any field because of its ever-expanding scope. As such, coding skills are becoming a necessity for anyone looking to work in digital or tech-related industries. Here are some benefits of learning to code that might help you decide if it\u2019s the right career path for you:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: The Basics of Coding for Beginners

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Even if you don\u2019t think of yourself as a tech whiz, you might find that coding is your calling. This can be a tricky subject to get started on and continue with, but we\u2019re here to make it easy for you. Coding for beginners isn\u2019t as difficult as you might believe, it just requires some study time and practice. It won\u2019t come easily at first, but with time and the right amount of dedication, anyone can learn the fundamentals of coding whether they have prior knowledge or not.
Coding is becoming one of the most important skills in today\u2019s job market. Even if you don\u2019t want to become a software engineer or the like, understanding basic coding principles can give you an edge in almost any other field. You see, anything from accounting to healthcare uses technology on a daily basis \u2014 often involving advanced software or artificial intelligence systems.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Coding is a hot job right now and will continue to be so for the foreseeable future. The demand for coders is growing, and not just in tech companies. Companies of all types need programmers with different coding skills to build their software and websites, which means that coders can find jobs anywhere.
Coding is also one of the fastest-growing job markets at the moment. As businesses continue to digitize and automate processes, the need for developers who can create programs increases as well. The explosion of new programming languages has made this an exciting time to be a coder. There are so many options out there \u2013 from traditional ones like Java and Python to newer players like Go and Kotlin. Which do you think makes for a more promising career as a coder? Keep reading to find out which coding languages are most in demand right now...`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: The Best Coding Shortcuts for Beginners

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`In the beginning, coding can feel like solving puzzles with red-hot needles in your hands. Everything is new, nothing makes sense and you can\u2019t even tell if you are on the right track or not. It feels like one confusing labyrinth with a lot of locked doors \u2013 every time you find an unlocked door, it just leads to another locked door! How do we get out of this frustrating loop? Coding shortcuts!
A lot of coders will tell you that in order to be a successful coder, you need to know everything about coding and all its ins and outs. However, there is a reason why even experienced programmers take note of coding shortcuts. These little tricks make life easier for anyone who is just getting started with coding and doesn\u2019t have time to invest in learning every last bit of it before they can start creating useful programs.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: The Best Coding Ides for Developers

It\u2019s important to find an environment that is both comfortable and productive, so you can get your work done faster and with the highest quality possible. relatedArticles.title: The Best Coding Tips for Beginners

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"There are plenty of reasons to learn how to code. This digital skill gives you the power to create websites, apps or video games from scratch without having to pay someone else to do it for you. Not only that, coding can be used in lots of different industries and jobs. It\u2019s also a great way to make money online as a side project if you have other ambitions. However, if you\u2019ve never coded before it can seem like an impossible challenge. It isn\u2019t something you can Google or Netflix your way through \u2014 it requires dedication and practice. Thankfully, there are plenty of free resources available on the Internet that will help you get started with coding basics and build your skills over time. The following article highlights some of the best tips for beginners who want to learn how to code in 2018 and beyond."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
